Evaporation rate at meniscus and in the middle of the glass should be the same if temperature of liquid and glass is the same. I think difference is in amount of alcohol around  evaporation area that can(or cannot) equalize the alcohol concentration rate of liquid at the area. For example in the middle there are a lot of alcohol molecules below the surface to fill in the concentration gap after some alcohol evaporated from the surface. While at meniscus there is a thin layer of liquid on the glass surface only, that cannot  provide enough alcohol to equalize that concentration ratio quick enough. This is why we are getting leaner solution/mix in the meniscus area.

It reminds me of the folk knowledge around certain food remedies-- people got better eating things with vitamin C because they were greatly deficient in it, not because vitamin C at any level would improve their health. We live in a world with competent bottled and storage and I wonder if even the $8 bottle of wine on the bottom of the shelf is considerably better than average compared to the wine that didn't have legs (rancid wine) that people might have drank in the past. It's not that the folk wisdom is wrong, it's just that we've moved so far along a bell curve of experience that we're now at the point where there's no discernible difference between samples.

Surface tension gradient - it is more of a surface tension step. The washing up liquid is made up of a chemical that has a longish tail - it has a hydrophilic end and a hydrophobic end. The ends sit side by side so that they form a sheet with the hydrophobic end away from the water and the hydrophilic end in the water. All you are doing when you put a drop of washing up liquid in there is allowing it to form a layer that is one molecule thick. If you know the concentration of detergent in the washing up liquid (you know the molecular formula of it) and how much is in there, you can measure the diameter of the cleared nutmeg ring (try lycopodium powder - it is better than nutmeg) and therefore you can work out the cross-sectional area of the molecules of detergent. knowing that, you can work out from the volume, what the length of the molecules is and therefore the thickness of the detergent film.

One of the really cool things about surface tension gradients is that the liquid will normally not be static (unless it's under very particular conditions). In other words, as long as there is a surface tension gradient, the liquid will be forced to flow! This can be shown mathematically by examining the directions of the stresses at the liquid interface.


Though it's not related to surface tension gradients, another interesting capillary flow phenomenon is the formation of coffee rings. All the sediment collects in a narrow annulus, because the fluid at the boundary of the puddle has more surface area, thus evaporating faster. The fluid from the inner region flows out to the perimeter to replenish the lost fluid, as the outer edge is basically pinned down due to adhesion and the puddle won't shrink. So this drives the sediment to form a ring.

Thats really interesting. When testing wine and talking about qualities of the wine, one usually doesn't just wait for the "legs" to form by Marangoni effect. Usually, one swirls the wine, causing the residual wine to drip down the sides, in "legs". We've always thought that the longer those legs run down the glass, the higher the residual sugar content in the wine, since dissolved sugars increase the viscosity of the wine. One can see this in the difference between ports (high sugar) and zinfandel (lower sugar). While the alcohol contents are slightly different (port is ~19%, zinfandels ~16-17%), the residual sugar contents are WAY different: an old vine zin has 3-5g of sugar per liter, most ports run around 100-150 g per liter. Consequently, the legs last way longer in a port than a dry wine. The difference between different wines can often show up as well in legs that are more or less persistent.


Incidentally, this formation of legs doesn't say anything about THE quality of the wine, rather about A quality, namely, the residual sugars. This can tell enthusiasts whether the grapes were likely harvested late or early, what type of grapes might be in a blend, etc. But given this interesting work here, I guess it also tells us about the potential alcohol content. One might guess that the sugar content will also have an effect on the surface tension gradients formed to make the Marangoni effect.

Well it can tell you about the quality, but only if you live in the US and the reason is taxes. Wine above 13.9% jumps into a higher tax bracket and is considered a "luxury good". So wineries aim for that 13-13.9% range to maximize value per unit for the consumer. It's what separates a $20 bottle from a $35 bottle. Naturally some people will pay extra for that nicer bottle with the higher ABV, so wineries make those too, and naturally they're going to be more selective about those grapes. You don't want someone to pay extra for a bottle and feel like they got ripped off.

Home wine-maker here, and I think I might have an explanation for why a wine is considered high quality if it has legs: glycerine.


Fermentation typically doesn't only produce ethanol. There's a whole bunch of other chemicals that get created depending on factors like fermentation temperature, pH, chemical composition of the initial must (for wine/cider) or wort (for beer), specific strain(s) of yeast being used, presence/absence and specific strains of malolactic bacteria during fermentation, material of the fermentation and aging vessels, etc.


One of the most important of these chemicals is glycerine, which gives wines like port and sherry their characteristic syrupy mouthfeel, and the resulting association with quality. Adding glycerine to improve a batch of wine is a very old trick, as a single teaspoon can turn a demijohn of meh wine into a good one in seconds. Checking for glycerine in table wine is also very easy, because the alcohol content alone isn't always enough for it to form legs, so you just stick it in a glass and swirl. That tiny amount of glycerine, about 0.1%, can make all the difference.

Good wine consists primarily of water and ethanol. Bad wine consists of water, ethanol, and a bunch of other alcohols, acids, etc. Many of these are a) poisonous or just taste bad, and b) evaporate slower than the ethanol, and they all reduce surface tension of water. So in the bad wine, the surface tension gradient is going to be smaller, resulting in legs not forming as easily. But yes, you should definitely be comparing two wines by that standard only if they have similar alcohol concentrations.

I think there's an opportunity for a follow-up on that bouncing effect. With the weight of the droplet falling down and the continuous motion of the film up the wall of the wine glass, you'd expect some sort of equilibrium to be reached -- it seems like a leap of logic to assert that two counteracting forces result in a oscillating motion. Also, you can see some really whacky effects if you place a splash of water and a splash of isopropyl alcohol on a horizontal glass surface such that they are touching each other -- all sorts of weird oscillatory motion as they try to mix. Given that the bulk of the wine has a higher alcohol content than the droplets, I'd expect the cause/explanation of the oscillations is the same, and somehow related to the different compositions/surface tensions of the liquids, but I'm yet to see a good explanation. But I feel like there's a mass transfer when the liquids touch, which causes a composition change, therefore surface tension change, therefore forcing the shape of the liquid surfaces to suddenly change.

“A poet once said, 'The whole universe is in a glass of wine.' We will probably never know in what sense he meant it, for poets do not write to be understood. But it is true that if we look at a glass of wine closely enough we see the entire universe. There are the things of physics: the twisting liquid which evaporates depending on the wind and weather, the reflection in the glass; and our imagination adds atoms. The glass is a distillation of the earth's rocks, and in its composition we see the secrets of the universe's age, and the evolution of stars. What strange array of chemicals are in the wine? How did they come to be? There are the ferments, the enzymes, the substrates, and the products. There in wine is found the great generalization; all life is fermentation. Nobody can discover the chemistry of wine without discovering, as did Louis Pasteur, the cause of much disease. How vivid is the claret, pressing its existence into the consciousness that watches it! If our small minds, for some convenience, divide this glass of wine, this universe, into parts -- physics, biology, geology, astronomy, psychology, and so on -- remember that nature does not know it! So let us put it all back together, not forgetting ultimately what it is for. Let it give us one more final pleasure; drink it and forget it all!”

~ Richard Feynman

I'm not totally convinced that that's why the droplets bounce. If it were because of the flow of the liquid under it, I think you'd see a the droplets slow down and then stop when the flow was large enough to overcome the weight of the droplet, and then the droplet would start growing and eventually just drop down to the liquid in the glass.

What I think is more plausible is that the droplets reach the liquid boundary (due to their weight) and are able to dump a tiny bit of water into the liquid. This makes the tip of the droplet a tiny bit less heavy, so the top of the droplet is then able to pull it back up momentarily (because of surface tension). Of course, there's still more fluid coming down, so the droplet starts growing again, becomes heavier, and the cycle starts again.
